p: Van Leuken et al. ( 2015b) described the application of an atmospheric dispersion model to the Dutch Q fever outbreak, namely the OPS-ST (Operational Priority Substancesâ€”Short Term) model (version 10.3.2). This model was developed by the Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) to describe the transport of gases and particles in the atmosphere (Van der Swaluw et al. 2011; Van Jaarsveld and Klimov 2011; Van Jaarsveld 2004). The OPS-ST model includes wet and dry deposition, but no (pathogen) inactivation. We assumed a steady-state emission strength and used all other configurations from Van Leuken et al. ( 2015b), i.e. the modelled concentrations were not calibrated using measured C. burnetii concentrations (since those were not available); rather, the model was validated with Q fever case notifications. Pathogens were represented by particulate matter (PM 10).
